title: Partnership with NOTOKYC
keyQuestions: What does “No-KYC” actually mean for users, and where are the real limits?
Why do independent catalogs matter when choosing an exchange route?
What signals indicate an anonymous swap service is reliable and consistent?
How do you reduce operational risk when swapping without identity checks?
What are the safest habits to keep privacy without making avoidable mistakes?
quickSteps: Choose a route that minimizes data collection and does not require identity checks.
Use verified links and bookmark the official domain before you start a swap.
Send a small test amount first if it’s a new route or a new wallet setup.
Keep your receiving wallet secure and back up recovery info offline.
Track the swap status via transaction IDs and avoid “support” links from DMs.

issueRouting.start: Decide what you’re optimizing for (privacy, speed, or simplicity). Then verify the route and keep operational hygiene tight: correct addresses, correct network, and verified pages.

then: Avoid reusing addresses and keep wallets separated by purpose.
Limit public sharing of TX links and consider private browsing for explorers.

branches.if: Your priority is speed and fewer steps
then: Prepare receiving addresses in advance and double-check the network.
Use small test swaps when the market is congested or fees are volatile.

branches.if: You are new to anonymous swaps
then: Start with a small amount and learn the flow end-to-end once.
Ignore impersonators: real support will not ask for seed phrases or remote access.

riskNotes: No-KYC does not remove market risk—prices, fees, and timing still matter.
Phishing and impersonation are the main operational threats; verify domains and links.
Avoid sharing sensitive details publicly; TX links and screenshots can leak patterns.
